Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Mechanobiology of Septins in the Cytoskeleton

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration: Understanding the mechanisms of how cells manipulate their own material properties will provide new ways to treat disease and a way to develop new engineering materials. The cells and tissues that make up living organisms have material properties just like any other substance. When exposed to mechanical forces, such as pulling or pushing, they stretch and change shape. They can even generate these forces themselves. The material properties of cells are controlled by the cytoskeleton, a collection of filamentous proteins. This network of filaments gives cells their shape, much like the skeleton defines the human shape. In cells, however, this network is dynamic and adaptive, reorganizing itself to help cells perform various functions or to resist outside mechanical stresses. The cytoskeleton thus represents a new class of material that doesn't obey the traditional models of engineering materials. It can modulate its material properties in both space and time. This Faculty Early Career Development Program (CAREER) project will determine how the cell is able to spatially and temporally regulate its material properties and unearth novel design principles that can be used to develop new engineering materials and to understand how some diseases affect cell behavior. Sitting at the interface between physics, biology, and engineering, this multi-disciplinary work will inform research across a broad spectrum of fields. Most importantly, it will create opportunities for a diverse set of students and young researchers to develop innovative skills and perspectives, in particular learning to communicate novel methods and ideas across disciplines. <br/><br/>The cytoskeleton is a model system for developing insights into non-equilibrium mechanics and network dynamics, and is known to both generate and respond to mechanical signals. Despite the fact that the principal molecular biochemical interactions have been well detailed, we still lack an understanding of how macroscopic scale behaviors emerge from the collection of many molecular interactions. Septins are the least studied filaments that make up the cytoskeleton. They bind to both actin and the plasma membrane, and have been shown to localize specifically to regions of actin curvature and mechanical stress. This research project will test the hypothesis that septins help to regulate the material properties of the cytoskeleton by altering the local architecture. This work will measure the material properties of septin-actin networks in both living cells and purified protein networks, and test the response of these networks to mechanical perturbations such as micropatterning to control cell shape, traction force microscopy, and optogenetics to induce local contractions. In addition to potentially uncovering novel mechanisms to regulate cell shape, this work will also generate insight into how molecular interactions in a network are integrated into macroscopic behaviors.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The cytoskeleton is the key structure that allows cells to change their shape. This ability is the basis of the most fundamental processes in cell biology including proliferation, cell migration and adhesion, and development. Septins are a subset of filamentous proteins that help make up the cytoskeleton and who localize at a number of locations that are associated with or subject to mechanical forces. The goal of this project was to determine whether septins are connected to mechanical signaling and stability of the cytoskeleton.

 

To address this question, we adapted and developed a number of techniques to both mechanically perturb the cytoskeleton and to measure protein response to these perturbations. We made use of established techniques including micropatterning to control cell shape, and optogenetics to alter mechanical signaling pathways. We also developed a new approach to use locally focused laser light to change tension in septin decorated structures. This technique allowed us to control these perturbations in both space and time, enabling clear, reproducible results showing recruitment of mechanosensitive proteins. While we did not find septins to be directly mechanosensitive, this technique did prove useful in identifying two other novel mechanosensitive proteins.

 

In place of sensing mechanical forces directly, we found that septins are particularly sensitive to changes in the architecture of the cytoskeleton. When the filaments in the cytoskeleton are disrupted, septins relocate to the cortex, or surface, of the cell. When the cell needs to change shape to squeeze through small spaces, septins relocate to the point of constriction. When we locally induce contraction by using light to turn on a signaling pathway, septins accumulate on cytoskeletal fibers in that region. Together all of these data suggest that septins are serving to support and potentially reinforce the cytoskeletal structure and buffer mechanical stresses on the cell. This is also consistent with previous reports that identify septins at other structures that are likely under mechanical stresses. Most excitingly, these data suggest that there separate signaling pathways that overlap, one biochemical and one physical, regulating septin activity.

 

Stepping back, these results align beautifully with the larger project goals of highlighting how biology and physics interact. Septins are clearly being regulated by a combination of both biochemical signaling and mechanical signaling. Most excitingly, the results from this project indicate that while these pathways overlap, they also exist as separate stimuli. One of the goals of this proposal was to stimulate biologists to think about physics, and physicists to think about biology. In that regard, we consider this work a great success and look forward to continuing to explore the fascinating overlap of these two disciplines as we pursue the functional role of septins in the cytoskeleton.
